A lot is hanging on the future of General Electric â€“ and not just the survival of one of the most famous business names in America. Last week a Nomura bank analyst warned that fixing GEâ€™s $115bn (Â£90bn) borrowing burden was â€œcriticalâ€� to keeping corporate Americaâ€™s $9 trillion debt pile on a stable footing. And GE is on the edge.

Jeff Bezos admitted last month that Amazon â€“ the worldâ€™s second-largest company â€“ would fail one day. It seemed an outlandish claim. But the sorry tale of GE shows that the impossible could happen.

In 2010 General Electric was still riding high as the largest company in the world. Its products ranged from fridges to jet engines and Hollywood blockbusters. Even now, power stations using GE equipment generate a third of the worldâ€™s electricity. But in June GE dropped out of the Dow Jones Industrial Average for the first time in 110 years â€“ the last of the original cohort to leave the famous index.

Since then things have only got worse. In October GE slashed its dividend from 12 cents to one cent per share, allowing it to save $3.9bn amid strained finances.

The proximate cause of the dividend cut was a $22bn accounting hit on power assets bought from the French firm Alstom in 2015. GEâ€™s chief executive, John Flannery, departed at the same time, leaving one of the titans of American industry on its third chief executive in 18 months and uncertain of its future path.

GEâ€™s size in the energy industry was no protection from a series of major missteps. Flanneryâ€™s predecessor, Jeff Immelt, made an ill-fated decision to target coal-fired power stations to feed the developing worldâ€™s voracious hunger for energy.

GEâ€™s executives were wrong. Global demand for traditional power generation equipment fell, while forecasts for renewable energy proved far too pessimistic a few years later as the cost of solar power plummeted. In December 2017 GE cut 12,000 jobs in its power business, nearly a fifth of the unitâ€™s workforce.

The $22bn writedown was in effect an acknowledgement that Immelt had massively overpaid for the Alstom assets after overestimating their future earnings potential. GE now faces the prospect of multiple regulatory probes over the accounting surrounding the acquisition.

GEâ€™s market capitalisation peaked in 2000, marking the high point for a firm that was a dominant presence on the American business landscape for more than 100 years. It is now worth about $70bn, having reached nearly $600bn in 2000.

The firm was founded in 1890 by Thomas Edison, the holder of 1,093 patents including the incandescent light bulb. But it was Jack Welch who shaped the modern GE. The chief executive expanded GEâ€™s market capitalisation by more than 30 times during his reign throughout the 1980s and the 1990s. Welch became a hero of American business, retiring in 2001 to a shower of hagiographic profiles.

Yet, like the long bull market, Welchâ€™s star waned, and the model of ruthless discipline that he had pioneered became discredited.

Tom Oâ€™Boyle, who traced Welchâ€™s corporate tactics in the book At Any Cost, said the chief executive sowed the â€œseeds of GEâ€™s destructionâ€� as part of his â€œreckless pursuit of profitâ€�.

â€œTheyâ€™ve been a hedge fund masquerading as an industrial titan since the Welch era,â€� Oâ€™Boyle said.

GE bet on its ability to use its financial heft and supposedly unique management style to take on businesses where it had little expertise. Recent years have been a catalogue of retreats. GE will sell its train manufacturing business, spin off its healthcare unit and sell down its majority stake in the oil-field services firm Baker Hughes. GE sold its remaining stake in NBCUniversal â€“ a combined TV and film group â€“ in 2013.

The biggest misstep was GE Capital, a financial services arm set up to help sell the core industrial products. The side business came to dominate, with the staggering success of GE Capital in the decade before the financial crisis coming to represent the bulk of profits for the whole company.

George Eckes, a consultant who worked with executives at the very top of GE before 2000, said that with hindsight GE had â€œfollowed this profit centre to the point of excessâ€�.

GE has broken with a long-standing tradition in its search for a solution, appointing the first outsider chief executive in its history, Larry Culp. Culp gained the approval of Wall Street as chief executive of the manufacturing conglomerate Danaher Corporation from 2000-14.

He may be forced to go back to the equity markets in 2019 to raise more cash to help cope with its debts, after telling the market the firm would miss profit targets for the year.

The company still has some strengths to fall back on: its jet engine business has been a bright spot throughout the turmoil, playing up to GEâ€™s strengths in high-value-added, precision industry.

â€œGE has considerable strengths,â€� said Culp in a call with analysts last month. â€œThe talent here is real, the technology is special and the global reach of the GE brand and our relationships are truly impressive, but GE needs to change.â€�

Spending at department stores fell for the 13th consecutive month in November, data has shown, as John Lewis revealed a rapid reversal in sales after the Black Friday bonanza.

Barclaycard usersâ€™ spending at department stores across the UK slumped 7.1% year on year during the month, according to the credit and debit card providerâ€™s latest monthly data, marking the sector out as one of the hardest-hit.

Sales of home technology, homewares and fashion all fell at John Lewis in the week to 1 December, resulting in a near 6% slide across the chain after a year-on-year 7.7% rise for the previous week, when the company benefited from the US-inspired discount day.

John Lewis blamed continued mild weather for poor sales of coats and knitwear, but its figures also reflect continuing difficulties for department stores in fighting the rise of online alternatives and a general decline in consumer confidence amid continued concerns about Brexit.

â€œDepartment stores took a pummelling in November,â€� said Laura Suter, a personal finance analyst at investment firm AJ Bell. â€œThe problems faced by the likes of House of Fraser and Debenhams, and questions about the storesâ€™ future, have likely put many off shopping with the brands.â€�

The latest poor figures come after the Sports Direct boss, Mike Ashley, said on Tuesday that it was getting tougher to achieve his aim of rescuing 80% of HoFâ€™s 59 stores. Ashley has called for a punitive tax on online retailers as he said many high streets were â€œalready deadâ€�.

Overall consumer spending rose 3.3% year on year in November, the lowest growth since March, despite the boost from Black Friday, according to Barclaycard.

Clothing spending contracted by 2.9%, the biggest fall since October 2017, while spending on household appliances was down by 14%.

Even discounters, who are widely seen as likely winners as families look for ways to save cash amid economic uncertainty, took a hit, with spending down nearly 17% year on year. However, spending at pubs and restaurants and on entertainment, particularly tickets for concerts, films and shows, was up.

Novemberâ€™s subdued figures reflect the cautious mood on the high street. Consumer confidence dropped by 3 percentage points to -13%, the lowest level this year, according to the long-running survey by research firm GfK.

And on Tuesday, Barclaycard said 52% of UK adults said they had confidence in their household finances â€“ the lowest level recorded since the company began tracking the data in 2015.

Primark sent a shiver through the high street on Friday as it warned of â€œchallengingâ€� trading conditions, with Brexit jitters threatening the busiest shopping weeks of the year.

Sales at the UKâ€™s third-largest clothing retailer, behind Next and the market leader M&S, have been bucking the high street gloom but Primark warned of subdued sales for November as fewer shoppers visited its stores.

The independent retail analyst Nick Bubb said the update would â€œstrike fearâ€� into fashion retailersâ€™ hearts because Primark is viewed as one of the sectorâ€™s more resilient names.

John Bason, the finance director of Primarkâ€™s parent Associated British Foods (ABF), cautioned: â€œThis isnâ€™t a call on Christmas â€“ weâ€™ve got three big weekends coming up now before Christmas. But I think it is a call on quite mild weather during November and I think itâ€™s affected footfall.â€�

Bason told Reuters that while sales at stores open more than one year were â€œjust positiveâ€� in September and October, they had turned negative in November. He declined to give precise numbers. ABF shares were the biggest fallers in the FTSE 100 on Friday, down more than more than 4%, despite the indexâ€™s rebound from its worst session since the day after the EU referendum in June 2016.

The Primark update added to evidence of a slowdown in British consumer spending in the run-up to Brexit. The troubled Ted Baker business reported disappointing figures on Thursday while John Lewis said sales had slumped in the wake of record takings during the week of Black Friday.

Novemberâ€™s subdued figures reflect the cautious mood on the high street. Consumer confidence dropped by three percentage points to -13%, the lowest level this year, according to the long-running survey by research firm GfK.

Overall consumer spending rose 3.3% year on year in November, the lowest growth since March, despite the boost from Black Friday, according to Barclaycard. Clothing spending contracted by 2.9%, the biggest fall since October 2017, while spending on household appliances was down by 14%.

Famed for its â€œcheap chicâ€�, Primark said that careful stock management, coupled with improved clothing profit margins, meant the retailer was still on track for bigger profits in the coming year. â€œItâ€™s a blip that from a profit perspective we can manage,â€� Bason said.

Primark will open more than 1m sq ft of new selling space in the coming year, with stores planned in mainland Europe as well as in the UK, including its biggest to date, a 160,000 sq ft branch in Birmingham Pavilions.

The crisis on Britainâ€™s high streets is to intensify this Christmas, with shopkeepers preparing themselves for the quietest festive period since the credit crunch, according to forecasts.

A combination of low consumer confidence because of Brexit, more agile online competitors and Christmas shoppers increasingly buying experiences such as concert tickets instead of products, will combine to ruin the season for more high-street stores, said the retail research group Springboard.

Footfall â€“ a measure of the number of shoppers visiting stores â€“ is expected to decline by 4.2% this month compared with the same time in 2017, when visitor levels fell by 3.5%.

If the Springboard prediction proves correct, it will be the ninth December out of the last 10 in which bricks and mortar retailers have attracted fewer shoppers.

Related: Spending at UK department stores falls for 13th month in a row

During the past decade, UK annual footfall has only risen once, during 2011, when shoppers started spending again after two depressing years in the depths of the financial crisis.

Diane Wehrle, a marketing and insights director at Springboard, said: â€œThere has been more discounting this year by retailers, Black Friday was not a success and there is low consumer confidence because of the maelstrom of Brexit. I think a number of retailers will be really pinched in the new year. Fashion and department stores are particularly vulnerable.â€�

The dire predictions come after Primark sent a shiver through the sector last week by warning of â€œchallengingâ€� trading conditions, with Brexit jitters threatening the busiest shopping weeks of the year.

Sales at the UKâ€™s third-largest clothing retailer â€“ behind Next and the market leader M&S â€“ have been bucking the high-street gloom, but Primark warned of subdued sales for November as fewer shoppers visited its stores.

Nick Bubb, a retail industry analyst, said the update would â€œstrike fearâ€� into fashion retailersâ€™ hearts because Primark is viewed as one of the sectorâ€™s more resilient names.

Related: Why switching on Christmas lights is now a big turn-off

The troubled business Ted Baker also reported disappointing figures last week, while John Lewis said sales had slumped after record takings during the week of Black Friday.

The subdued figures reflect the cautious mood on the high street.

Consumer confidence dropped by three percentage points to -13% last month, the lowest level this year, according to the long-running survey by the research company GfK. Overall consumer spending rose 3.3% year-on-year in November, the lowest growth since March, despite the boost from Black Friday, according to Barclaycard. Clothing spending contracted by 2.9%, the biggest fall since October 2017, while spending on household appliances was down by 14%.

Springboard said footfall in November fell by 3.2%, a significant decline on the previous year when it grew by 0.2%. Last month also represented the 12th month of consecutive decline by this measure, with the numbers illustrating how the online-focused Black Friday shopping spree had an impact.

The news also comes after prices in British shops rose for only the third time in five years in November, pushed up in part by higher global costs for commodities such as wheat.

Retailers, who have held down their prices in the face of tough online competition and weaker household spending power, lifted their prices by an annual 0.1% in November, the British Retail Consortium and the market research company Nielsen said.

Mike Ashley is not everyoneâ€™s favourite retailer, but the boss of Sports Direct certainly knows a thing or two about his industry. So when he says that November trading was the â€œworst on record, unbelievably badâ€� itâ€™s worth taking notice.

To be sure, the Ashley warning needs to be taken in context. When he said that some retailers would be smashed to pieces, one of those he clearly had in mind was Debenhams, in which Sports Direct has a near-30% stake. Ashleyâ€™s very public warning that Debenhams risks going under was designed to force the management of the department store chain into accepting his â€“ so far spurned â€“ offer of financial help.

But it is not just Debenhams that is suffering. The clothing company BonmarchÃ© has put out a profits warning in which it says current trading conditions are worse than they were during the financial crisis of a decade ago. John Lewis has reported year-on-year falls in sales of between 5.1% and 8.3% in four out of the past five weeks, the one exception being the week of Black Friday, when retailers make little profit as a result of the discounts on offer.

Even Primark, one of the UKâ€™s most resilient retailers, has reported challenging trading conditions in recent weeks.

Nor is it just retailers that are struggling. Restaurant chains, normally packed out with Christmas parties at this time of the year, are being forced to offer big discounts to attract customers. The latest report from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) has also revealed that the housing market is at its weakest in six years, with a marked absence of both buyers and sellers.

All this is happening at a time when pressures on household budgets have eased. After a tough 2017, wages have again started to rise more quickly than prices. Employment is at record levels and there are plenty of job vacancies.

But whereas a year ago consumers were prepared to run down their savings in order to fund their spending habits, this year they are doing the opposite. They are spending less, borrowing less and thinking twice about racking up debts on their credit cards. There are going to be some huge bargains on offer between now and Christmas as retailers slash their profit margins to shift stock.

Itâ€™s not hard to find an explanation. Consumers have taken fright at the impasse in the Brexit negotiations and become more cautious. Business investment has been weak for months as companies put spending plans on hold, and households have now joined them in their wait-and-see approach. The economy has gone into Brexit lockdown.

When in Rome â€¦ do what the European commission says

Italy is on the brink of recession. The economy contracted marginally in the third quarter of 2018 and there are signs that the final three months of the year will bring more of the same. Nothing new about that. The Italian economy has grown by just 0.4% a year on average over the past two decades.

In the most recent elections, the Italian people decided they had had enough of technocratic governments that insisted the way forward was a programme of structural reform â€“ the usual diet of making it easier for employers to hire and fire, privatisation and less-generous welfare benefits â€“ and opted for something different. Two populist parties, the League and the Five Star Movement, were elected on a bog-standard Keynesian platform of boosting demand by running a bigger budget deficit.

Unsurprisingly, this behaviour fell foul of the two custodians of financial orthodoxy, the European commission and the bond markets. Brussels demanded that the Rome government rethink its plan to run a budget deficit of 2.4% of GDP in 2019 and the markets rammed home the message by making it more expensive for Italy to service its whopping national debt.

Rome has now said it will run a smaller deficit of 2.04% next year and even though the concession might not be enough to satisfy the commission, the markets have responded by driving down Italian bond yields.

As an explanation of why voters are sick of political and financial elites, this could not be improved upon. Voters tire of a failed economic model and demand an alternative that would once have been considered mainstream. The commission says that alternative is not permissible and when the government does as it is told it is rewarded by the financial markets. Not hard to see why people are taking to the streets.

Employment is at record levels and there are plenty of job vacancies. But whereas a year ago consumers were prepared to run down their savings in order to fund their spending habits, this year they are doing the opposite. They are spending less, borrowing less and thinking twice about racking up debts on their credit cards. Consumers have taken fright at the impasse in the Brexit negotiations and become more cautious. As an explanation of why voters are sick of political and financial elites, this could not be improved upon. Voters tire of a failed economic model and demand an alternative that would once have been considered mainstream. The commission says that alternative is not permissible and when the government does as it is told it is rewarded by the financial markets. Not hard to see why people are taking to the streets.

Believe in reform of the audit market only when the government legislates to make it happen, but the start of the process carries a welcome whiff of seriousness.

One canâ€™t call the proposals radical, because many of the recommendations are merely commonsense solutions to ancient problems. Action should have happened a decade ago when the banks, boasting healthy reports from their auditors, fell over. Instead, and slightly oddly, the collapse of Carillion became the final embarrassment.

Sir John Kingman, representing one half of a pincer movement, says the Financial Reporting Council, the audit watchdog, has taken â€œan excessively consensual approach to its workâ€� and should be abolished. Good. The credibility of the FRC, sadly, has sunk too low and the charge of institutional capture has lingered for too long. A â€œfresh startâ€�, as Kingman put it, is needed.

Related: Big four accounting groups escape breakup threat from CMA

For this reform to be convincing, however, the FRC canâ€™t simply be rewired as the Audit, Reporting and Governance Authority. Kingmanâ€™s call for â€œnew leadershipâ€� is just as important as his demand for â€œnew powersâ€� and â€œa new mandateâ€�. A cosmetic exercise wonâ€™t do.

Proposals from the Competition and Markets Authority, examining market structure, could be more far-reaching. The CMA did not recommend a breakup of the big four auditors, which is probably sensible given the complexity of these international networks of firms. But an internal operational split between audit and non-audit activities is overdue.

And an insistence of joint audits at FTSE 350 companies â€“ with one firm being drawn from outside the big four â€“ could have long-lasting benefits. In about a decadeâ€™s time, one could imagine a top league of eight auditing outfits, with underperformers at risk of relegation.

That, at least, is the hope. It is now vital that the government does not go limp in the face of the inevitable criticism that reform, and more intrusive regulation, will be expensive. Better-quality audits are worth paying for.

Asosâ€™ margins should match its size

Asosâ€™s heavy profits warning is merely â€œa bump in the roadâ€� and the ambitions for the business remain intact, declared chief executive Nick Beighton. He scores top marks for optimism, but Asos investors may feel the refrain is alarmingly familiar.

Back in 2014, Asos hit a similar bump. Profit margins, which had been running at 7%-8%, would have to be lowered to 4%-ish for a while, the company said, reassuring shareholders that a dose of short-term financial pain was necessary to pursue the main prize of becoming the worldâ€™s biggest online fashion retailer for twentysomethings. The important thing was to build more warehouses and distribution infrastructure. The share price tanked at the time, but 4% was meant to be the low point for margins. The market trusted that it was.

Related: Asos issues shock profit warning after November downturn

Now, after only three months of Asosâ€™s latest financial year, Beighton says margins of just 2% are on the cards this time. Itâ€™s a huge turnaround from the confident outlook in October, when Asos unveiled pre-tax profits above Â£100m for the first time. On the latest forecast, the group will slide to Â£52m, which was roughly the return in 2014, when turnover was less than half the current level. Asos seems to be very good at selling more clothes to more people, but less effective at turning extra sales into extra profits.

For true believers, the long-term will still look lovely. Didnâ€™t Amazon run with negligible profit margins for years? Doesnâ€™t the US, where a first warehouse has been opened in Atlanta, represent a huge opportunity? Itâ€™s clearly possible that life will turn out so happily since, even in a soggy year, Asos still expects to grow sales by 15%. Itâ€™s just that financial success, in terms of hard profits and meaningful margins, forever seems to lie over the horizon.

The horrible retailing climate doesnâ€™t help, but the specific worry about Asos is that the competition is catching up. Its online world suddenly seems overpopulated with companies with an equal willingness to invest first and worry about profit margins later. Black Friday was a case in point. Asos pursued its usual â€œ20% offâ€� approach, but found others â€“ by which it may mean big German group Zalando â€“ going lower. Nor is it only a UK problem that could pinned on Brexit. France and Germany were also weaker than expected.

Asos has little choice but to keep running down the same road, whatever the bumps. Maybe the prize at the end isnâ€™t mega-returns, but a permanent state of low-margin attrition. Asos is no longer a small company. Even on the lower forecasts, it will shift Â£2.7bn worth of fast fashion items this year. In that context, a 2% profit margin looks extremely thin. Shouldnâ€™t a few economies of scale have arrived by now?

Didnâ€™t Amazon run with negligible profit margins for years? Doesnâ€™t the US, where a first warehouse has been opened in Atlanta, represent a huge opportunity? Itâ€™s clearly possible that life will turn out so happily since, even in a soggy year, Asos still expects to grow sales by 15%. The horrible retailing climate doesnâ€™t help, but the specific worry about Asos is that the competition is catching up. Its online world suddenly seems overpopulated with companies with an equal willingness to invest first and worry about profit margins later. Black Friday was a case in point. France and Germany were also weaker than expected. Asos has little choice but to keep running down the same road, whatever the bumps. Maybe the prize at the end isnâ€™t mega-returns, but a permanent state of low-margin attrition. Asos is no longer a small company. Even on the lower forecasts, it will shift Â£2.7bn worth of fast fashion items this year. In that context, a 2% profit margin looks extremely thin. Debenhams, a stalwart of the British high street with 165 UK stores and sales of Â£2.9bn, has sunk in value to below a 24-store fishing tackle chain in a situation that lays bare the changing face of retail.

Fears that the department store group is heading for the rocks sent its shares down a further 5% on Friday to a new low of 3.8p. This values the group at Â£46.6m â€“ about Â£8m less than the fast-growing fishing specialist Angling Direct, which was founded 14 years ago and has annual sales of about Â£30m.

Debenhams traces its history to 1778 and it was once a constituent of the FTSE 100 index of the biggest companies. As its value declined, it was relegated to the FTSE 250, but lost its place last year and is now worth less than a raft of retailers including Superdry, Halfords and Carpetright, the struggling floor coverings specialist, which closed 92 stores via an insolvency procedure this year.

Shares in the group, which is weighed down by more than Â£300m of debt, have sunk nearly 90% this year after three profit warnings, as it struggles to adapt to changing shopping habits and increased competition.

Department stores, once a popular choice for branded merchandise inc, are under threat from online rivals, including beauty specialists such as Cult Beauty and Feelunique as well as the likes of Amazon and Asos.

In October, Debenhams announced a near Â£500m loss as well as plans to shut up to 50 stores.

Last week, Mike Ashley, the boss of the House of Fraser owner Sports Direct â€“ which appears poised to make a move for Debenhams should its financial position worsen â€“ said the high street faced being â€œsmashed to piecesâ€� by a savage downturn this Christmas.

In contrast, Angling Direct, which began with fishing tackle shops in Norfolk, has been expanding, opening its 24th store in Peterborough this year. This week the company revealed a Â£31.5% rise in sales to Â£14.6m in the four months to the end of November, including a 24.3% rise in sales online. Its shares rose more than 4% on the news.

The chain is thriving, even as rival Fishing Republic, which has 14 stores, called in administrators on Thursday. Andrew Poxon and Julien Irving of Leonard Curtis Business Rescue & Recovery, who were appointed joint administrators, said they had sold the company to a third party, saving 111 jobs.

Specialist retailers such as Angling Direct, with a limited number of small stores, a strong online presence and close contact with a well-defined customer base, are seen as the potential future of the industry.

John Stevenson, a retail analyst at the City broker Peel Hunt, said: â€œThose retailers that will be successful will not have massive stores with long leases and are relevant to their customer. They are absolutely focused on putting the customer first.â€�

But he said Debenhams was likely to miss its profit targets due to unseasonably warm weather, low consumer confidence and increased competition from online, alongside the chainâ€™s specific problems with tired stores and product ranges.

â€œEven if it gets through Christmas and comes out the other side OK, the outlook is one of the most challenged retailers in the market,â€� Stevenson said.

Wall Street stocks fell in volatile trading on Friday, with the Nasdaq, Dow and S&P 500 on pace for their worst month since 2009.

After another day of highly volatile trading the tech-heavy Nasdaq sank to a 15-month low, falling as much as 21.5% from its 29 August high. The benchmark S&P 500 index, already on pace for its biggest percentage decline in December since the Great Depression, hit its lowest level since August 2017. The Dow Industrials fell to the lowest level since October 2017.

All three indexes swung between losses and gains of more than 1%. They received a momentary boost after the New York Fed president, John Williams, said on CNBC that the Fed is open to reassessing its views and monitoring market signals that economic growth could fall short of expectations.

That news helped drive shares higher overseas. In London the FTSE closed 9 points higher at 6,721.

But those gains soon evaporated as economic worries again prevailed. Williamsâ€™ dovish comments could point to hidden concerns among some Fed policymakers, said Tim Ghriskey, the investment strategist at Inverness Counsel in New York.

â€œ(Williamsâ€™ comments) helped the markets for a while early on, and then it was just a sell-off after that,â€� Ghriskey said. â€œPart of that is when the Fed says something like theyâ€™re re-looking at things, thereâ€™s a concern that maybe the Fed knows something that we donâ€™t know.â€�

Related: US stock markets drop amid interest rates hike and looming shutdown

Technology and communication services stocks bore the brunt of the sell-off, falling 2.3% and 2.7%, respectively.

The so-called Faang group â€“ Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google â€“ fared poorly. Facebook shares tumbled 5.4%, Amazon shares slid 4.8% and Netflix shares sank 5%. Shares of both Apple and Google parent Alphabet dropped more than 2%.

Turmoil in Washington injected further pessimism into US stock markets. Donald Trump said there was a very good chance a government funding bill, which included funding for a wall along Mexico border, would not pass the Senate.

â€œThe market continues to react to the possibility of a government shutdown, fear of a domestic and global slowdown and general displeasure about the direction of Fed policy,â€� said Ryan Larson, the head of US equity trading at RBC Global Asset Management in Chicago.

Nikki Mitchellâ€™s trolley was laden with her Christmas turkey and Christmas sprouts, but there was space left for Christmas broccoli or Christmas blackberries. Unfortunately, her local supermarket had run out. â€œIâ€™m going to have to come back, but itâ€™s not that bad,â€� she said, surveying the checkout queues with her husband, David. â€œItâ€™s busy but it hasnâ€™t been as busy as I expected. Probably the hardest thing was getting a trolley â€“ we had to accost someone on the way out.â€�

Yesterday, dubbed Super Saturday by struggling but hopeful retailers, was for many the opportunity for a last-chance dash to the shops before Christmas. And the supermarkets were primed: the aisles of Mitchellâ€™s local Tesco in London were stacked with turkeys of every kind, a dozen types of mince pie and festive spirits by the litre. Tesco said it had sold 4 million bags of carrots, Sainsburyâ€™s had 300 Christmas lines on sale, and Aldi was expecting 2 million shoppers â€“ its highest ever. Most of these shops were also selling partridges, if not pear trees.

To soothe the nerves of panicking customers, the supermarkets have extra staff to keep shelves stocked and work the tills. Waitrose â€“ which expects today to be its busiest day â€“ has five â€œturkey runnersâ€� in each shop to give out click-and-collect orders. Sainsburyâ€™s has recruited an extra 6,000 workers, with staff from head office adding another 4,000 shifts. Asda has recruited so-called Christmas Champions to help. Waitrose, like the others, is extending its opening hours and has lorries leaving its distribution depots every 74 seconds.

If this all sounds a bit stressful, it is. With a nod to the customer who want to shop in peace, Morrisons switched off all its music yesterday and muted the tills so that the only beeps would come from the queues for the car park.

More and more customers, however, do the Christmas food shopping online, for either delivery or in-store collection. Sainsburyâ€™s said yesterday that it had made 220,000 deliveries since Thursday â€“ about one a second â€“ and even discount stores, such as Aldi, and small chains like Londis and Spar, have an online offering.

Not everyone is a fan of this. Yesterday Ethel Abalake was picking up some last-minute bits, having bought a Â£27 turkey the day before. Sheâ€™s catering for 20, but prefers to wait in queues than go online. â€œI donâ€™t like shopping online,â€� she says. â€œI go to the shops to see it before I buy it.â€�

Supermarkets have a problem with online shopping that is not shared with retailers such as Amazon, which last week was criticised for leaving parcels in bins or throwing them over fences. You canâ€™t do that with a carton of eggs, although some unhappy customers think their drivers may have tried, and have turned to social media to vent their frustration. Complaints range from the failed attempt of a soldier in Afghanistan to send a hamper to his aged mother and items delivered being almost out of date to orders being cancelled completely.

Drivers feel under pressure too. The number of orders is the same as at other times of year, but in each one there are three times as many boxes to deliver, which means more vans making more trips, according to an Ocado driver who did not want to be named.

One Asda driver, who also wanted to remain anonymous, said a new â€œdark storeâ€� â€“ a warehouse laid out like a supermarket where the only â€œcustomersâ€� are packers â€“ didnâ€™t have enough capacity for the number of vans it was serving. That meant more substituted items, and more disgruntled customers, he said. An alternative, pioneered by Ocado, has robots bringing the items to the packers, who can finish a shop in five minutes.

â€œWeâ€™re still in the early stages of online food, and itâ€™s all about market share,â€� said Richard Lim of analyst Retail Economics. â€œRetailers are really investing in the long-term potential of online. But their margins are wafer- thin: a typical Â£80 food order costs Â£5 to pick and Â£5 to deliver. Retailers are working on about 4% to 5% margins so theyâ€™re not making any discernible profit from this.â€�

Supermarkets and retailers are all nervous about Christmas. Operating costs are rising faster than profits, creating a â€œreally hostileâ€� environment for shops, Lim said. Saturday daytime â€œfootfallâ€� â€“ the number of people visiting shops in high streets, retail parks and shopping centres â€“ is 10% down on last year, according to analyst Springboard, which believes Boxing Day footfall will be down 5.2%.

â€œWages are up and inflation is down,â€� Lim said, â€œwhich would suggest thereâ€™s more spending power. But that differs massively among income groups.â€� He cited an income tracker by Asda and the Centre for Economics and Business Research that shows the poorest 20% of households have seen their discretionary spending fall every month since June 2016.

â€œOverall, I think Christmas is going to be tough this year.â€�

Stock markets around the world have staged a post-Christmas rally after shares on Wall Street soared sharply higher after their worst ever performance on Christmas Eve.

Related: Markets braced for turmoil as Trump and Christmas sell-off feed uncertainty

After wobbling at the open the S&P 500 Index, the DowJones and Nasdaq had all recorded significant gains by the end of Wednesday. The Dow added over 1,080 points (4.9%), its biggest points gain in history, the S&P rose 4.9% and the Nasdaq, which has suffered the most in recent falls, closed 5.8% up.

Asia Pacific markets followed Wall Streetâ€™s lead on Thursday with the Nikkei up 3.9% in Tokyo to take it out of the bear market it entered with a 5% drop on Christmas Day. In Sydney, the benchmark ASX200 index closed up 1.9%.

The FTSE100 is expected to open up 1.5% when trading begins in London later on Thursday.

But analysts said that the fundamental concers of investors about the global economy and trade had not disappeared.

â€œInvestors are aware of negative factors, but they arenâ€™t paying attention to those. They are looking at the Dowâ€™s 1,000 gain,â€� said Norihiro Fujito, chief investment strategist at Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities in Tokyo.

â€œI think worries regarding the US government shutdown as well as lack of clarity over whether the US-Sino negotiations (over trade) will go well or not still remain.â€�

The Dow and S&P 500 dropped more than 2.5% on Christmas Eve, their worst ever pre-holidays performance. Worries about rising interest rates, Donald Trumpâ€™s attacks on the Federal Reserve for raising those rates, a government shutdown and the continuing trade tensions between the US and China have all rattled investors and the major indices were on the brink of a bear market â€“ a 20% fall from their most recent high.

US stock markets have enjoyed a record-breaking run, rising steadily since March 2009, the low point of the financial crisis. And the wider economy appears robust with unemployment low and inflation in check. But despite evidence that the US economy remains robust, this year could still mark the first bear market in close to a decade.

On Monday the Dow was off 18.8% from its October high, while the S&P had fallen 19.8% from its record. The tech-heavy Nasdaq index is already in a bear market, down 23.6% from its August record. The soaring share prices of technology companies â€“ especially the so-called Faang companies, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google â€“ helped push stock markets to new highs. There recent losses have been a major factor in dragging the markets down.

With just four more trading days to go until the end of the year, investors are expecting a bumpy ride.

Much of the headwinds have come out of Washington. On Christmas Eve Trump tweeted: â€œThe only problem our economy has is the Fed. They donâ€™t have a feel for the Market, they donâ€™t understand necessary Trade Wars or Strong Dollars or even Democrat Shutdowns over Borders. The Fed is like a powerful golfer who canâ€™t score because he has no touch - he canâ€™t putt!â€�

The latest attack contributed to Mondayâ€™s sell-off and came as economists wrestled with a government shutdown, sparked by Trumpâ€™s attempts to fund his border wall with Mexico. That shutdown is now in its fifth day with no signs of a resolution.

Trump has since tried to walk back his criticism of the Fed, telling reporters at the White House on Tuesday that while the Fed was â€œraising interest rates too fastâ€� he still had confidence in the central bank. â€œI mean, the fact is that the economy is doing so well that they raised interest rates and that is a form of safety in a way,â€� he said.

Peter Cardillo, chief market economist at Spartan Capital Securities in New York, told Reuters that he expected markets to continue to rally as investors looked for bargains. But he warned there was probably more volatility ahead. â€œThe â€˜bear gripâ€™ is feeding on itself as Trump continues to spread uneasiness,â€� said Cardillo.

January

â€¢ Days into 2018, the government outsourcing and construction business Carillion collapsed into bankruptcy. Its chairman, Keith Cochrane, chief executive, Richard Howson, and former finance directors Zafar Khan and Emma Mercer were eventually branded â€œdelusionalâ€� by MPs as the full extent of the failings at the company became clear in bruising hearings. The bankruptcy is estimated to have cost the taxpayer Â£150m.

â€¢ Julian Dunkerton, the founder of Superdry, cashed out Â£18m in shares of the fashion retailer shortly before he quit the brand he started in 2003. Those shares are worth about one-quarter of that now, after a torrid year for British retailers, affected by shoppers moving online, Brexit uncertainty and unseasonable weather. The sale might have been good timing â€¦ but the value of his remaining 18% stake has since been hammered and is down more than Â£230m. The former boss â€“ who quit the company in March â€“ is not happy. Dunkerton reckons he could do a better job than its chief executive, Euan Sutherland, and has launched a comeback campaign.

â€¢ Bruce Ritchie, a Mayfair property developer who founded Residential Land, and David Meller, from the luxury good specialist Meller Group, are now better known as the men behind the Presidents Club. The all-male event was shut down after the Financial Times revealed alleged sexual harassment at a black-tie dinner, and shone a light on sexism in the City. Meller was forced to resign from the board of the Department for Education in the aftermath.

February

â€¢ The Conservative MP Nicky Morgan has set about chairing the Treasury select committee in the same spirit as her predecessors, holding the governmentâ€™s feet to the fire on Brexit and keeping the financial sector on its toes. In February, the committee made public a confidential report by the Financial Conduct Authority into misconduct at Royal Bank of Scotlandâ€™s global restructuring group.

March

â€¢ Michael Spencer, the City financier and former Conservative party treasurer, netted Â£670m when the company he founded, Nex Group, was bought by CME Group, the worldâ€™s largest exchange.

â€¢ Barbara Judge was chairwoman of the Institute of Directors and known as the best-connected woman in Britain until March. She had prestigious roles before becoming the IoDâ€™s first female head, but this ended in ignominy after allegations of racism and bullying within the organisation, which focuses on promoting good corporate governance.

April

â€¢ Mike Coupe, the chief executive of Sainsburyâ€™s, shocked the retail world when the FTSE 100 company and its Walmart-owned rival Asda announced plans for a merger to create the countryâ€™s biggest supermarket. Coupe was then filmed, ahead of an interview on ITV, singing â€œWeâ€™re in the moneyâ€�. The deal and his song, Sainsburyâ€™s insisted, were unconnected.

â€¢ Jeff Fairburn, a former chief executive of Persimmon, was handed a pay packet that was more like a lottery win, with a Â£110m bonus after the housebuilderâ€™s profits were pumped up, in part by the governmentâ€™s help-to-buy subsidy. In April, despite widespread outrage, investors voted 51% to approve it . Persimmon eventually cut Fairburnâ€™s bonus to Â£75m and he promised to set up a charitable foundation. Fairburn finally lost his job in November after a disastrous local TV interview, but he keeps the money â€“ and there is still no sign of that charitable foundation.

May

â€¢ Liv Garfield, the chief executive of Severn Trent and the FTSE 100â€™s youngest female boss at 43, picked up Veuve Â­Clicquotâ€™s prestigious Business Woman of the Year award. Garfieldâ€™s rapid ascent started at BT and she joined the water utility in 2014. But her biggest challenge could lie ahead: if Labour wins the next election, the water companies are top of John McDonnellâ€™s list for nationalisation.

â€¢ As chief executive of TSB, Paul Pester had big plans to make the high-street challenger a real force in British banking. But then came a massive computer glitch, which resulted in millions of customers being locked out of their bank accounts, some for several weeks. Pester did not react well to questioning by MPs, and was forced to forfeit his bonus in May. By September he was an ex-chief executive.

June

â€¢ Sir Martin Sorrell, the former chief executive of WPP, had quite a year. He resigned abruptly in April from the company he transformed from a wire shopping basket manufacturer into a global marketing and advertising group. His departure came after allegations of â€œpersonal misconductâ€�, which he denied. In June came allegations that he had been spotted by colleagues entering premises in Mayfair used by sex workers. An investigation found there was no proof of misuse of company money and Sorrell, 73, has since bounced back with a new advertising company.

â€¢ Richard Branson, the billionaire owner of the Virgin empire, enjoyed a healthy bump in his already considerable wealth in June as CYBG, the owner of the Clydesdale and Yorkshire Bank brands, swooped for Virgin Money in a Â£1.7bn deal to create the UKâ€™s sixth-largest lender. Branson owned a 35% stake, and will continue to earn licensing revenues as the Virgin brand is extended across the UK.

July

â€¢ Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive of Amazon, became the worldâ€™s richest person as a result of rising technology share prices. By September, the company was worth $1tn (Â£790bn) and Bezos was worth more than $160bn. Since then, tech stocks have fallen sharply.

â€¢ Sundar Pichai, Googleâ€™s chief executive, has had a tough year at the helm of the company whose motto used to be â€œdonâ€™t be evilâ€�. In July, Pichai had to contend with a Â£3.8bn fine and dressing down from the European commission after competition concerns on its Android operating system. Since then, there have been internal sexual harassment protests and a row over plans to produce a censored search engine for China.

August

â€¢ Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, will for ever be the man who led the first listed company to a valuation of more than $1tn. However, the trillion-dollar landmark did not last long amid a deep market sell-off in October and concerns that iPhone sales growth was waning â€“ with particular attention on the troublesome Chinese market.

â€¢ Elon Musk, the founder of Tesla, is hailed by many as a visionary, but even visionaries have to abide by market abuse rules. So when he tweeted in August â€“ reportedly while driving himself to work â€“ that he had â€œfunding securedâ€� for a private buyout of the electric carmaker, an immediate investigation was launched. It was not Muskâ€™s only controversial moment this year â€“ he also called a British cave diver trying to rescue trapped Thai boys a â€œpedoâ€� (prompting a defamation lawsuit) and was pictured smoking marijuana while recording a podcast.

September

â€¢ Rupert Murdoch, the billionaire owner of News Corporation, may have failed in his aim to take over the broadcaster Sky, but the Â£12bn payday for 21st Century Fox when it sold shares will probably sweeten the pill. Murdoch is also in the process of a separate $71.3bn sale of Fox to Disney. Comcast ended up paying Â£30bn for Sky, significantly more than the Â£18bn bid made by Fox in December 2016.

â€¢ Dara Khosrowshahi, the chief executive of Uber, has tried to take a different path from its founder, Travis Kalanick, and his abrasive manner since taking over in August 2017. However, changing the ride-hailing companyâ€™s culture has proved to be no easy feat: Khosrowshahi was forced to apologise for the appâ€™s mistakes in London in September, a year after Transport for London moved to remove its licence in the capital.

October

â€¢ The former deputy prime minister Nick Clegg once said he was not very impressed by Facebook. â€œIâ€™m not especially bedazzled by Facebook,â€� he wrote in 2016. â€œI actually find the messianic, Californian new-worldy, touchy-feely culture of Facebook a little grating.â€� But then he lost his parliamentary seat and his career trajectory started to head south â€“ and took a new job in the US as global head of communications at Facebook. One of his top priorities will be to avoid a regulatory showdown with Brussels at a time when Facebookâ€™s policies and behaviour are under scrutiny, not least after Sheryl Sandberg was accused of condoning a smear campaign against the financier George Soros.

â€¢ Sir Philip Green, the owner of Topshopâ€™s parent company, Arcadia, is no stranger to controversy, but this autumn he was named in parliament as the man behind multiple non-disclosure agreements. The NDAs still hold, but Green has denied â€œunlawful sexual or racist behaviourâ€�.

November

â€¢ Denise Coates, the chief executive of Bet365, is the best-paid woman in Stoke, and the rest of the world, for that matter. Coates turned her fatherâ€™s bookmaker into one of the worldâ€™s biggest online gambling businesses. Her record Â£265m annual pay packet provoked criticism, but it is a private, family owned company and she controls it.

â€¢ Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault, apparently had little idea that he was about to be arrested and detained when he arrived in Tokyo in November. The Lebanese-Brazilian executive, who forged an alliance between Franceâ€™s Renault and Japanâ€™s Nissan and Mitsubishi, was shopped by Nissan for allegedly underreporting his income. The Japanese carmakers quickly ousted him from their boards, leaving the alliance â€“ and Ghosnâ€™s freedom â€“ in the balance.

December

â€¢ Ray Kelvin was probably the biggest name in retail no one had heard of â€“ until 300 former and current employees of his Ted Baker fashion business signed a petition on the campaigning website Organise complaining about his behaviour, including â€œforced hugsâ€� and ear kissing. The company said Kelvinâ€™s hugs were â€œpart of Ted Bakerâ€™s culture, but are absolutely not insisted uponâ€�. But then details of an office brawl emerged â€“ which had earned Kelvin a formal warning â€“ and â€œfurther serious allegationsâ€� eventually prompted the rag trade multimillionaire to take a leave of absence while an independent investigation is carried out.

â€¢ It has not been such a great year for Nick Robertson, the co-founder of Asos. He has watched the value of his stake in the online fashion retailer fall by about 70% â€“ or Â£275m â€“ between its peak in March and the aftermath of a shock profit warning in December. The British retail sector laboured during 2018, but analysts were taken aback by declining margins online at a time when most eyes were on the travails of the high street.

Branson owned a 35% stake, and will continue to earn licensing revenues as the Virgin brand is extended across the UK. July â€¢ Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive of Amazon, became the worldâ€™s richest person as a result of rising technology share prices. By September, the company was worth $1tn (Â£790bn) and Bezos was worth more than $160bn. Since then, tech stocks have fallen sharply. â€¢ Sundar Pichai, Googleâ€™s chief executive, has had a tough year at the helm of the company whose motto used to be â€œdonâ€™t be evilâ€�. In July, Pichai had to contend with a Â£3.8bn fine and dressing down from the European commission after competition concerns on its Android operating system. Since then, there have been internal sexual harassment protests and a row over plans to produce a censored search engine for China. August â€¢ Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, will for ever be the man who led the first listed company to a valuation of more than $1tn. However, the trillion-dollar landmark did not last long amid a deep market sell-off in October and concerns that iPhone sales growth was waning â€“ with particular attention on the troublesome Chinese market. â€¢ Elon Musk, the founder of Tesla, is hailed by many as a visionary, but even visionaries have to abide by market abuse rules. So when he tweeted in August â€“ reportedly while driving himself to work â€“ that he had â€œfunding securedâ€� for a private buyout of the electric carmaker, an immediate investigation was launched. In October, the US Securities and Exchange Commission forced him to resign the role of chairman (though not chief executive) and fined the billionaire $20m. It was not Muskâ€™s only controversial moment this year â€“ he also called a British cave diver trying to rescue trapped Thai boys a â€œpedoâ€� (prompting a defamation lawsuit) and was pictured smoking marijuana while recording a podcast. September â€¢ Rupert Murdoch, the billionaire owner of News Corporation, may have failed in his aim to take over the broadcaster Sky, but the Â£12bn payday for 21st Century Fox when it sold shares will probably sweeten the pill. Comcast ended up paying Â£30bn for Sky, significantly more than the Â£18bn bid made by Fox in December 2016. â€¢ Dara Khosrowshahi, the chief executive of Uber, has tried to take a different path from its founder, Travis Kalanick, and his abrasive manner since taking over in August 2017. However, changing the ride-hailing companyâ€™s culture has proved to be no easy feat: Khosrowshahi was forced to apologise for the appâ€™s mistakes in London in September, a year after Transport for London moved to remove its licence in the capital. The NDAs still hold, but Green has denied â€œunlawful sexual or racist behaviourâ€�. November â€¢ Denise Coates, the chief executive of Bet365, is the best-paid woman in Stoke, and the rest of the world, for that matter. Coates turned her fatherâ€™s bookmaker into one of the worldâ€™s biggest online gambling businesses. Her record Â£265m annual pay packet provoked criticism, but it is a private, family owned company and she controls it. â€¢ Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault, apparently had little idea that he was about to be arrested and detained when he arrived in Tokyo in November. The Lebanese-Brazilian executive, who forged an alliance between Franceâ€™s Renault and Japanâ€™s Nissan and Mitsubishi, was shopped by Nissan for allegedly underreporting his income. The Japanese carmakers quickly ousted him from their boards, leaving the alliance â€“ and Ghosnâ€™s freedom â€“ in the balance. December â€¢ Ray Kelvin was probably the biggest name in retail no one had heard of â€“ until 300 former and current employees of his Ted Baker fashion business signed a petition on the campaigning website Organise complaining about his behaviour, including â€œforced hugsâ€� and ear kissing. The company said Kelvinâ€™s hugs were â€œpart of Ted Bakerâ€™s culture, but are absolutely not insisted uponâ€�. But then details of an office brawl emerged â€“ which had earned Kelvin a formal warning â€“ and â€œfurther serious allegationsâ€� eventually prompted the rag trade multimillionaire to take a leave of absence while an independent investigation is carried out. â€¢ It has not been such a great year for Nick Robertson, the co-founder of Asos. The last 12 months have proved difficult for investors in stock markets around the world as fears over global growth mount up, and for many owners of commodities 2018 has proven equally tricky, my colleague Jasper Jolly writes:

8.32am GMT

Australiaâ€™s stock exchange has closed for the year, after yet another day of losses.

The S&P/ASX200 index dipped by 0.14%, taking its combined losses in 2018 to over 9% - the worst year since 2011.

Related: Australian shares have worst year since 2011 amid growing economic concerns

8.20am GMT

Another reason to worry about Chinaâ€™s economy:

8.20am GMT

In a worrying signal for 2019, Chinaâ€™s manufacturing sector is now contracting.

The official factory Purchasing Managersâ€™ Index (PMI) fell to 49.4 in December, official data shows, a two-year low.

Thatâ€™s below the 50-point mark that shows if activity rose or fell.

Manufacturers were hit by falling orders, with new export orders dropping for the seventh month in a row. That suggests the tariffs imposed on Chinese goods at the US border are hitting demand.

Mike Van Dulken of City firm Accendo Markets says this data â€œmay fan the flames of concern about slowing global growthâ€�. More here.

8.07am GMT

The worst-performing market this year? China.

Chinaâ€™s stock markets have suffered a particularly bleak 2018.

The Shanghai composite index has crashed by 25% this year, leaving investors suffering very heavy losses.

The trade war with the US has acted like a lead weight on many stocks, of course, but thereâ€™s also concern that Chinaâ€™s economy is weakening.

My colleague Lily Kuo explains:

â€œPeople have started to reduce or even stop spending money because they donâ€™t expect the economy will perform well,â€� said Ye Tan, an independent economist based in Shanghai. â€œCompanies and individuals are wary about the economy.â€�

Going into 2019, China faces not just a slowing economy but also a protracted trade war with the US, a pile of debt that threatens the world economy along with the Chinese financial system, and a populace demanding better environmental, labour, and health protections.

Related: China: slowing economy and inequality force new priorities for rulers

Shanghai is closed today, as China prepares for the New Year celebrations. Investors deserve the break.

7.43am GMT

Introduction: 2018 and all that selling

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business.

Itâ€™s the final day of the year, and many investors will forgiven for wishing â€˜goodbye and good riddanceâ€™ to 2018.

The last 12 months have been pretty tough in the markets. Global stocks have suffered their worst losses since the financial crisis of 2008, wiping around 11% off the MSCI All Country World Index of stocks.

In London, the FTSE 100 is limping towards the end of a rough year. The blue-chip index has shed 12% of its value since the start of January, hitting a series of two-year lows -- in a blow to pension funds and savers big and small.

The big worry is that the long bull market, which reared up after the great recession ended in 2009, is now over.

Anxiety over trade wars, a slowing global economy, Donald Trumpâ€™s increasingly erratic behaviour and US interest rate hikes have all hurt stocks this year.

In Europe, the tortuous Brexit negotiations and the long-running row between Italyâ€™s populist government and Brussels have also worried investors.

Trevor Greetham of Royal London Asset Management explains:

We were surprised at the ferocity of the selloff in December which we put down to rising nervousness about the US-China trade dispute, an ill-judged and poorly communicated rate hike from the US Federal Reserve and an increasingly erratic pattern of behaviour from President Trump as the Mueller investigation into Russian collusion enters its final stages.

â€œThe last couple of weeks have seen a surprise unilateral decision to pull all US troops out of Syria, threats of a â€œvery longâ€� government shutdown if Congress refuses to fund the Mexican border wall and a counterproductive attempt to blame the Fed for market weakness when itâ€™s the trade war that investors are most worried about.

â€œElsewhere in the world Theresa Mayâ€™s chaotic postponement of the meaningful vote on the EU Withdrawal Bill has added to the jittery mood in markets, raising as it does the risk of a No Deal Brexit that would damage both the UK and euro area economies.

But perhaps investors are too gloomy.

Over the weekend, Donald Trump and Xi Jinping both made positive noises about a breakthrough in their trade talks, offering hope that deeper tariffs can be avoided.

Related: China's Xi Jinping calls on Donald Trump for trade compromise

That is likely to give traders some much-needed optimism today. European markets are expected to open higher today, in a shortened trading session (although Germany and Italy will be closed).
